perturbation.original_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Company elects to abandon any patent application, to not pay maintenance fees or annuities to keep a patent in force, or to otherwise take or fail to take any action that will result in a loss of patent rights, Company shall give Investor at least sixty (60) days prior written notice and an opportunity to take over the prosecution of the patent application that would be abandoned and/or pay the fees necessary to keep the patent in force and/or take any other action necessary to avoid the loss of patent rights.
perturbation.changed_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Company elects to abandon any patent application, to not pay maintenance fees or annuities to keep a patent in force, or to otherwise take or fail to take any action that will result in a loss of patent rights, Company shall give Investor at least ten (10) days prior written notice and an opportunity to take over the prosecution of the patent application that would be abandoned and/or pay the fees necessary to keep the patent in force and/or take any other action necessary to avoid the loss of patent rights.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for patent abandonment to 10 days may be insufficient under patent law and best practices. It might not provide the investor with adequate time to assess the patent's value and arrange for continued prosecution, potentially violating their rights and creating a legal challenge.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Patent Law - reasonable time for patent prosecution takeover

perturbation.original_text: Investor at any time may provide written notice to Company of a material breach of this IP Agreement. If Company fails to cure the identified breach within thirty (30) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.changed_text: Investor at any time may provide written notice to Company of a material breach of this IP Agreement. If Company fails to cure the identified breach within five (5) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach to 5 days may be considered unreasonably short, especially for complex breaches. This could be seen as a violation of fair dealing and good faith principles, potentially making the termination clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - reasonable cure period for breach of contract

perturbation.original_text: If the Parties cannot resolve any Dispute for any reason, including, but not limited to, the failure of the Parties to agree to enter into mediation or agree to any settlement proposed by the mediator, within sixty (60) days after the Escalation to Mediation Date, either the Company or the Holder may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with Article 18.04.
perturbation.changed_text: If the Parties cannot resolve any Dispute for any reason, including, but not limited to, the failure of the Parties to agree to enter into mediation or agree to any settlement proposed by the mediator, within fifteen (15) days after the Escalation to Mediation Date, either the Company or the Holder may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with Article 18.04.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the dispute resolution period to 15 days after mediation escalation is likely insufficient for complex IP disputes. This rapid escalation to litigation could be viewed as a failure to engage in good faith negotiation and mediation, potentially violating legal standards for alternative dispute resolution and increasing litigation costs unnecessarily.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law/ADR - Sufficient time for mediation/dispute resolution
